articles.headline: What You Need to Know About Biden’s Student Loan Forgiveness Plan
articles.snippet: President Biden’s move means the student loan balances of millions of people could fall by as much as $20,000. This F.A.Q. explains how it will work.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s move means the student loan balances of millions of people could fall by as much as $20,000. This F.A.Q. explains how it will work.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden announced on Wednesday that the federal government would cancel up to $20,000 worth of federal student loans for millions of people. But not everyone with debt will qualify.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Google Finds ‘Inoculating’ People Against Misinformation Helps Blunt Its Power
articles.snippet: British researchers and a team from Google found that teaching people how to spot misinformation made people more skeptical of it.
articles.abstract: British researchers and a team from Google found that teaching people how to spot misinformation made people more skeptical of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the fight against online misinformation, falsehoods have key advantages: They crop up fast and spread at the speed of electrons, and there is a lag period before fact checkers can debunk them.
articles.byline: By Nico Grant and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Democrats Sense a Shift in the Political Winds, but It May Not Be Enough
articles.snippet: A series of strong special election showings, culminating in a New York win, have buoyed Democratic confidence, but a daunting map may still cost them the House.
articles.abstract: A series of strong special election showings, culminating in a New York win, have buoyed Democratic confidence, but a daunting map may still cost them the House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Energized abortion-rights voters. Donald J. Trump back in the spotlight. Stronger-than-expected special elections, including a surprising win early Wednesday in New York.

articles.headline: Facebook, Twitter and Others Remove Pro-U.S. Influence Campaign
articles.snippet: It was the first time that an influence operation promoting U.S. interests abroad had been discovered and taken down from the social media platforms.
articles.abstract: It was the first time that an influence operation promoting U.S. interests abroad had been discovered and taken down from the social media platforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and Twitter have removed an influence operation from their networks that promoted U.S. foreign policy interests abroad, according to a report on Wednesday by researchers from the Stanford Internet Observatory and the research company Graphika.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Defiant Under Russian Strikes, Ukrainians Celebrate a Nation ‘Reborn’
articles.snippet: At least 22 people were killed in a missile strike on a rail station in eastern Ukraine, officials said. Celebrating the country’s Independence Day, Ukrainian leaders urged resolve.
articles.abstract: At least 22 people were killed in a missile strike on a rail station in eastern Ukraine, officials said. Celebrating the country’s Independence Day, Ukrainian leaders urged resolve.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Under the blare of air raid sirens, Ukrainians celebrated their Independence Day with a show of defiance against Russia’s invasion on Wednesday, despite the uncertain course of a war that has lasted half a year and brought horror to nearly every part of the country.

articles.headline: Pace of Climate Change Sends Economists Back to Drawing Board
articles.snippet: They underestimated the impact of global warming, and their preferred policy solution floundered in the United States.
articles.abstract: They underestimated the impact of global warming, and their preferred policy solution floundered in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: Why Is This Colorful Little Wheel Suddenly Everywhere in Japan?
articles.snippet: It’s the logo of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals. And Japan is all in.
articles.abstract: It’s the logo of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals. And Japan is all in.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A few years ago, a colorful new accessory suddenly began to appear on the lapels of dark-suited salarymen across Japan: a small badge, shaped like a roulette wheel and divided into 17 rainbow-colored sections.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: Dollar Stores Report Higher Sales as Shoppers Seek Inflation Relief
articles.snippet: American consumers are gravitating toward less expensive stores as inflation drives up rent, food and fuel costs.
articles.abstract: American consumers are gravitating toward less expensive stores as inflation drives up rent, food and fuel costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The two largest chains of dollar stores in the country posted higher sales and profits in their latest quarter, a sign that consumers are flocking to discount retailers as rapid inflation eats into their budgets.

articles.headline: Judge Orders Redacted Affidavit Used in Trump Search Warrant to Be Unsealed
articles.snippet: The document will be unsealed by noon Friday. In its most complete form, it would disclose important details about the government’s justification for searching Mar-a-Lago this month.
articles.abstract: The document will be unsealed by noon Friday. In its most complete form, it would disclose important details about the government’s justification for searching Mar-a-Lago this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the affidavit in the search of Trump’s Mar-a-Lago home.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Why Europe’s Electricity Prices Are Soaring
articles.snippet: Reverberations from the war in Ukraine have “distorted” the market for natural gas, forcing energy prices up.
articles.abstract: Reverberations from the war in Ukraine have “distorted” the market for natural gas, forcing energy prices up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Energy traders in Europe are witnessing price increases that are hard to fathom. Natural gas, which is used to generate electricity and heat, now costs about 10 times more than it did a year ago. Electricity prices, tied to the price of gas, are also several times higher than what used to be considered normal.
